doc.field: The sayinges or proverbes of King Salomon
The sayinges or proverbes of King Salomon
sayinges or proverbes of king salomon
sayinges or proverbes of king salomon
The sayinges or proverbes of King Salomon
<displayTitle>The sayinges or proverbes of King Salomon</displayTitle>
<title type="main">The sayinges or proverbes of King Salomon</title>
<title type="main">The sayinges or proverbes of King Salomon</title>

The sayinges or prouerbes of king Salomon /with the answers of Marcolphus /tr?slated out of frenche into englysshe. Salomon. He that wyll measure Of all the sees the water Is nat very sage. Marcolphus. He that holdeth in his honde The faythe of an hore/as a good bonde He is full of rage. Salomon. Caste a stone at an ape Or a staffe/ if that he scape The more wyll he mowe and moyle. Marcolphus. Gyue to a hoore her askynge Outher late or in the mornynge The more she wyll you dispoyle. Salomon. A house that in euery cornere Letteth in wynde/sone burneth clere Whan fyre therin taketh. Marcolph. A hoore that is gay Is redy nowe and alway Whan that she money seth. Salomon. Who so euer hath sycknesse Is very ioyfull I gesse Whan he with lyfe dothe scape. Marcol. He that a hoore byleueth Nothynge with hym abydeth Nouther mantell nor cape. Salomon. No man shall knowe or marke A coler in the darke Paynted on a spoone. Marcol. Nor a preuy hoore Taken shall be at any houre In doynge/by nyght or noone. Salomon. A conye hymselfe hydeth And depely he ofte dyggeth Yet at last is he take. Marcol. A hoore so moche plucketh I man/and on hym laugheth That she hym maketh leane as a rake. Salomon. At a Ouen mouthe/that is hot That thynketh yerbes shuld growe for the pot Of trouth he is begyled. Marcol. He that withouten fayle Putteth his hande to a hores tayle Shall haue it soone defyled Salomon. Charge vpon a beest Money or leade in a chest Whether/they nothyng care. Marcol. A hoore taketh no kepe What man on her dothe leape All is to her one fare. Salomon. A horse that his brydell hath on He is redy anon For to go on his waye. Marcol. A hoore clothed gayly Is soone made redy To begyn her ioye. Salomon. He that in his house as lefe Cheryssheth a thefe Shall receyue great domage. Marcol. He that an hoore kepeth to honoure At thende he shall wepe and loure Whan he knoweth her vsage. Salomon. A man so longe may chase Through woddes and playne percase That at last he shall be wery. Marcol. Many a hoore oft clotheth And brede to her gyueth That with other she is more mery. Salomon. The oxe of the villayne His brede dothe often gayne Wherwith he lyueth here. Marcol. He bosteth hym selfe in vayne That thynketh a hoore certayne To slee with his gere. Salomon. He that to a dogge sayth haue He wyll anone his tayle waue And than he hym fawneth. Marcol. He that to a hoore sayth holde She byddeth hym be bolde All is redy that he c?maundeth Salomon. Men accompte them as wyse as fooles That the burnynge coles In their bosomes wyll hyde. Marcol. For a foole he is tolde That wasteth all his golde To clothe a hoores syde. Salomon. Stockfysshe is of valewe none Except it be trewly layde vpon And often tourned and beaten Marcol. A rybaude she is lost If she be nat well beate and tost And vnder fote troden. Salomon. The ape is a beest lothsom And of a counterfayte fasshyon It hath so shorte a tayle Marcol. So counterfayte is none parde But by money haue shall he Of a hoore his wyll without fayle. Salomon. The lytell cockerell Eateth his meate well In crowynge he nedeth no scole. Marcol. A hoore her selfe clotheth And also she fedeth With the money of a foole. Salomon. An asse in close kept fast Ryseth vp in haste Whan he seeth pasture. Marcol. He that a hoore for hym selfe kepeth She often another in his sted taketh Whan his money no lenger wyll endure. Salomon. The thorne in a hedge taketh And the woll of plucketh Of shepe and of mottons. Marcol. A hoore plucketh away The money day by day Of all maner companyons. Salomon. Mortalyte and great warre Be exyled farre Fro all maner of men. Marcol. For a hoore all myschefe Mortalyte/warre and great grefe C?meth soone agayne. Salomon. The fawcon is well loued And of the fawconer well reclaymed By his gentle deporte. Marcol. He that a hoore wyll leade Thorough the sees/in tyme of nede Shall neuer haue good porte. Salomon. He is a fole without fayle And leseth his trauayle That layeth a fox to slepe. Marcol. He is more foole for certayne That perceyueth a hoore wolde parte fayne And seketh meanes her styll to kepe. Salomon. The fowler there his net layeth Where as he comonly seeth Byrdes fede and rest. Marcol. A hoore foloweth that waye Where as she seeth a pray Of Rybawdes a great nest. Finis.
